unnormalised: The week has brought a mixed bag of fortunes for Indian athletes, with injury updates casting a shadow over several promising careers. Let's delve into the latest reports:

unnormalised: Hardik Pandya, the star all-rounder, remains sidelined after sustaining an ankle injury during the ICC World Cup 2023 match against Bangladesh at the MCA Stadium in Pune on Oct 19th. Initial reports suggested a recovery timeline of several weeks. While he has been undergoing intensive rehabilitation at the National Cricket Academy (NCA) in Bengaluru, a definitive return date remains uncertain. "We are monitoring Hardik's progress closely," stated a BCCI official earlier this week. "The focus is on ensuring a full recovery rather than rushing him back into action." The absence of Pandya is a significant blow to the Indian team, leaving a void in both the batting and bowling departments. Fans will remember his fiery performance against Pakistan at the Asia Cup in Sri Lanka.

unnormalised: PV Sindhu, the two-time Olympic medalist, is currently recovering from a knee injury. This setback forced her to withdraw from the recently concluded Syed Modi International Badminton Championships in Lucknow. While the exact nature of the injury hasn't been disclosed, sources close to the athlete have indicated that it’s a nagging issue she has been managing for a while. It is hoped that this period of rest and rehabilitation will allow her to return to full fitness before the Paris Olympics qualifiers intensify. Just like in the movie *Chak De! India*, we all hope Sindhu returns stronger and ready to take on the world.

unnormalised: The Indian men’s hockey team is dealing with concerns surrounding defender Harmanpreet Singh. During the Asian Champions Trophy in Chennai in August, he sustained a minor hamstring strain. While he participated in subsequent tournaments, whispers suggest the issue hasn't completely resolved. The team management is carefully managing his workload to avoid any further aggravation, especially with the crucial Pro League matches and Olympics qualifiers on the horizon.

unnormalised: Neeraj Chopra, India’s golden boy, is reportedly experiencing minor discomfort in his throwing arm. He has been undergoing physiotherapy sessions in his training camp in Patiala. While it's not considered a serious injury, his team is taking a cautious approach, ensuring he is at peak fitness for the upcoming Diamond League series. An official statement indicated, "Neeraj is feeling some minor discomfort, but it is nothing alarming. We are taking all necessary precautions to ensure he is 100% fit before his next competition." The nation awaits Neeraj to reach the magical 90m mark.
